The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_uint8_to_str_pad:
```c
size_t
MHD_uint8_to_str_pad (uint8_t val,
                      uint8_t min_digits,
                      char *buf,
                      size_t buf_size)
{
  size_t pos; /**< the position of the current printed digit */
  int digit;
  mhd_assert (3 >= min_digits);
  if (0 == buf_size)
    return 0;

  pos = 0;
  digit = val / 100;
  if (0 == digit)
  {
    if (3 <= min_digits)
      buf[pos++] = '0';
  }
  else
  {
    buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) digit);
    val %= 100;
    min_digits = 2;
  }

  if (buf_size <= pos)
    return 0;
  digit = val / 10;
  if (0 == digit)
  {
    if (2 <= min_digits)
      buf[pos++] = '0';
  }
  else
  {
    buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) digit);
    val %= 10;
  }

  if (buf_size <= pos)
    return 0;
  buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) val);
  return pos;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: No uses of <string.h> functions are present in the supplied function (no memcpy/memmove/memset/strcmp/strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strncat/strlen/strspn etc.), so Rule 21.17 (which applies specifically to the standard string handling functions) has no direct application here. Additionally, buffer writes are guarded: an early check returns when buf_size == 0, and before each subsequent digit write the code checks if (buf_size <= pos) and returns if there is no space remaining. Thus there are no obvious code fragments in this function that could cause accesses beyond the buffer bounds via standard <string.h> calls or via unguarded writes. Consequently no fragments require further investigation for Rule 21.17.
